intent: Foundational cybersecurity concepts, models, and vocabulary for Nyx/Marion to reason with defensively and explain clearly.

principles.name: CIA Triad
principles.summary: Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability: the classic security outcome goals.
notes: Use as a simple mental model; modern programs also emphasize privacy, safety, and resilience.

principles.name: Least Privilege
principles.summary: Grant only the minimum access needed, for the minimum time needed.
notes: Pair with periodic access reviews and just-in-time (JIT) access where possible.

principles.name: Defense in Depth
principles.summary: Multiple overlapping controls so a single failure doesn’t become a full compromise.
notes: Avoid piling controls without threat-model logic; layers should be purposeful.

principles.name: Assume Breach
principles.summary: Design as if compromise will happen; optimize for detection and containment.
notes: This is a posture, not paranoia: it drives telemetry and response readiness.

principles.name: Secure by Default
principles.summary: Systems should start in a safe configuration; requiring insecure opt-ins is a failure mode.
notes: Combine with secure-by-design and secure-by-deployment guidance.

models.name: Threat Actor / Capability / Intent
models.summary: Model threats by who might attack, what they can do, and why they’d do it.
steps: Identify plausible actors (opportunistic, criminal, insider, nation-state).
Assess capability (tools, access, skill) and intent (motive).
Map to likely attack paths and mitigations.

models.name: Intrusion Kill Chain (high-level)
models.summary: A generic sequence of attack stages (recon to actions on objectives) to plan detections and controls.
notes: Use at a high level; avoid turning it into operational offensive guidance.

models.name: Zero Trust (outcomes view)
models.summary: Continuously verify and minimize trust: strong identity, device posture, least privilege, segmentation, and telemetry.

vocabulary.definition: Anything of value to protect: data, systems, credentials, people, reputation.
All the ways an attacker can interact with or reach a system (interfaces, endpoints, users).
A weakness that can be exploited to violate security properties.
A potential cause of an unwanted incident (actor + capability + intent).
Likelihood × impact of a threat exploiting a vulnerability against an asset.
examples: credential theft leading to account takeover

vocabulary.definition: A safeguard that reduces risk (prevent, detect, respond, recover).

foundational_topics.name: Identity & Access Management (IAM)
foundational_topics.summary: Authentication, authorization, lifecycle management, and monitoring of identities.

foundational_topics.name: Logging & Telemetry
foundational_topics.summary: Visibility is a prerequisite for detection and response; logs should be meaningful and protected.

foundational_topics.name: Vulnerability & Patch Management
foundational_topics.summary: Identify, prioritize, and remediate known weaknesses in a disciplined cadence.

foundational_topics.name: Backups & Recovery
foundational_topics.summary: Resilience against ransomware and failures depends on tested backups and recovery procedures.
